definition: to open the back door/fig. under the counter/to do a secret or dishonest deal/to let sth in by the back door

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format
empress/queen/(archaic) monarch/ruler
back/behind/rear/afterwards/after/later/post-
surname Hou

gate/door/CL:扇[shan4]/gateway/doorway/CL:個|个[ge4]/opening/valve/switch/way to do something/knack/family/house/(religious) sect/school (of thought)/class/category/phylum or division (taxonomy)/classifier for large guns/classifier for lessons, subjects, branches of technology/(suffix) -gate (i.e. scandal; derived from Watergate)
surname Men

sentences.english: He tried opening the back door with the key.
sentences.chinese: 他试着用这把钥匙开后门。

sentences.english: It gives a new method of putting backdoor .
sentences.chinese: 这给了一个新的方法去开后门。

definition: lit. to enter by the back door/fig. to gain influence by pull or unofficial channels/back door or under the counter connections
to pass a message
to give the green light/to give the go-ahead
to use social connections/to toady to influential people
to seek contact with sb for one's own benefit/to suck up to sb
to intercede/to plead for sb else
see 走門路|走门路[zou3 men2 lu4]
to seek help from social connections
the back door/fig. under the counter (indirect way for influence or pressure)/anus
favoritism shown to sb because of the influence of the person's wife or other female relative/(by extension) favoritism towards relatives, friends or associates
lit. to make sb wear tight shoes (idiom)/to make life difficult for sb
(coll.) to gain profit (usu. by underhand means)
to tout/to solicit customers
to buy a title/to use wealth to acquire office
to make extra money
to raise a tough question
